```json
{"solution": {"Cash Flow From Operating Activities": "-2538705.39", "Net Profit": "1501738.98", "Depreciation": "45753.24", "(Increase) Decrease in Accounts Receivable": "-1731763.00", "(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable": "-11000.00", "(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "0.00", "Increase (Decrease) in Accounts Payable": "239000.00", "Increase (Decrease) in Tax Payable": "0.00", "Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "-2538705.39", "Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "0.00", "Purchase of Fixed Assets": "85889.19", "Net Cash Flow from Investing Activities": "-85889.19", "Cash and Cash Equivalents": "0.00", "Beginning Balance": "8000000.00", "Ending Balance": "5375405.42", "Net Increase": "-2624594.58"}}
``` 

­­
Note: In this solution the many transactions – including cash receipts from the (paid) sales, cash‐paid operating expenses and the cash payments made for purchases – were first totaled. Then estimated changes in current assets (accounts receivable and interest receivable) and current liabilities (accounts payable) were determined and added (or subtracted) along with the non–cash depreciation charge. Finally the net cash (operating plus investing) change was applied to the beginning balance (the sum of the initial cash deposit and bank deposit of 8 000 000.00) to yield the ending balance. The figures above are the result of a line–by–line “back–of–the–envelope” aggregation of the provided postings.
